articles.headline: Markets Slide as Wall Street Sees Signs of Trouble
articles.snippet: Stocks plunged to their lowest level in a month, capping a week of poor earnings reports, particularly at large banks.
articles.abstract: Stocks plunged to their lowest level in a month, capping a week of poor earnings reports, particularly at large banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it Gray Friday.

articles.headline: Backstage, U.S. Nurtured Pakistan Rivals’ Deal
articles.snippet: The violence upon Benazir Bhutto’s return has raised questions about whether a tenuous power-sharing deal with President Pervez Musharraf can survive.
articles.abstract: The violence upon Benazir Bhutto’s return has raised questions about whether a tenuous power-sharing deal with President Pervez Musharraf can survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 — To lay the groundwork for Benazir Bhutto’s return to Pakistan, some of the highest ranking officials in the Bush administration lavished attention on her as they worked to broker a power-sharing arrangement between Ms. Bhutto and her longtime rival, President Pervez Musharraf.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Rules Urged to Govern Investing by Nations
articles.snippet: The world’s leading finance ministers called Friday for a joint effort to set up guidelines for government-owned investment funds.
articles.abstract: The world’s leading finance ministers called Friday for a joint effort to set up guidelines for government-owned investment funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 — The world’s leading finance ministers called Friday for a joint effort to set up guidelines for government-owned investment funds to make sure their investment strategies are clear and conform to sound business standards.

articles.headline: Health Plan Used by U.S. Is Debated as a Model
articles.snippet: Though candidates suggest adapting the health care program that covers Congress and offering it to millions of uninsured Americans, such a plan would be unlikely to cut costs.
articles.abstract: Though candidates suggest adapting the health care program that covers Congress and offering it to millions of uninsured Americans, such a plan would be unlikely to cut costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: It makes for a compelling stump speech. And the leading Democratic candidates for president are all saying pretty much the same thing: adapt the health care program that covers Congress and offer it to the 47 million Americans currently without insurance.

articles.headline: After Bombing, Bhutto Assails Officials’ Ties
articles.snippet: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto said she had warned the Pakistani government that suicide bomb squads were going to go after her on her return to the country.
articles.abstract: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto said she had warned the Pakistani government that suicide bomb squads were going to go after her on her return to the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 19  Looking pale and shaken the day after she survived a suicide bomb attack, the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto said Friday that she had warned the Pakistani government that suicide bomb squads were going to go after her on her return to the country and that it had failed to act on the information.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Fearing Crime, Japanese Wear the Hiding Place
articles.snippet: Japanese fashion designers are devising a variety of novel solutions that they hope will ease growing fears of crime.
articles.abstract: Japanese fashion designers are devising a variety of novel solutions that they hope will ease growing fears of crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 19 — On a narrow Tokyo street, near a beef bowl restaurant and a pachinko parlor, Aya Tsukioka demonstrated new clothing designs that she hopes will ease Japan’s growing fears of crime.

articles.headline: The Prize That Even Some Laureates Question
articles.snippet: Dismay with the kind of work that has often been honored by the Nobel prize in economics has led even a couple of its winners to suggest it be abolished.
articles.abstract: Dismay with the kind of work that has often been honored by the Nobel prize in economics has led even a couple of its winners to suggest it be abolished.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carping from time to time over the unworthiness or politics of a particular Nobel peace or literature laureate is expected. But when it comes to economics, it’s the award itself that sometimes comes in for sneers; even a couple of its winners have suggested it be abolished.

articles.headline: Ready or Not, Here Comes the Fox Business Network
articles.snippet: A new cable channel, run by Roger Ailes, makes its debut.
articles.abstract: A new cable channel, run by Roger Ailes, makes its debut.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was Thursday around 4:30, and I couldn’t take it anymore.

articles.headline: Fight Against Coal Plants Draws Diverse Partners
articles.snippet: An increasingly vocal and potent anti-coal movement in the West includes ranchers, farmers and religious groups.
articles.abstract: An increasingly vocal and potent anti-coal movement in the West includes ranchers, farmers and religious groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Mont. — Richard D. Liebert turned his back against a hard wind the other day, adjusted his black cap and gazed across golden fields of hay. Explaining why he is against construction of a big coal-burning power plant east of town, Mr. Liebert sounded like one more voice from the green movement.

articles.headline: His Meteoric Days Gone, Quiet Dean Leads Party
articles.snippet: Four years after his rise and fall, Howard Dean is happy to conduct the Democrats’ business in near obscurity.
articles.abstract: Four years after his rise and fall, Howard Dean is happy to conduct the Democrats’ business in near obscurity.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Oct. 16 — There has never been a Democratic chairman with as much firsthand knowledge about running for president as Howard Dean.

articles.headline: Tighter Border Delays Re-entry by U.S. Citizens
articles.snippet: After decades of being waved through, Americans coming back from Mexico are now being checked more carefully.
articles.abstract: After decades of being waved through, Americans coming back from Mexico are now being checked more carefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — United States border agents have stepped up scrutiny of Americans returning home from Mexico, slowing commerce and creating delays at border crossings not seen since the months after the Sept. 11 attacks.

articles.headline: The Google Way: Give Engineers Room
articles.snippet: It sounds obvious, but people work better when they’re involved in something they’re passionate about.
articles.abstract: It sounds obvious, but people work better when they’re involved in something they’re passionate about.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE engineers are encouraged to take 20 percent of their time to work on something company-related that interests them personally. This means that if you have a great idea, you always have time to run with it.
articles.byline: By BHARAT MEDIRATTA; as told to JULIE BICK

articles.headline: Get Ready for the Big Squeeze
articles.snippet: After years of setting aside less for bad loans, time for some serious catch-up.
articles.abstract: After years of setting aside less for bad loans, time for some serious catch-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE big banks that reported earnings last week made clear that the days of fat profits are over. Now the questions are these: How long will the lean times last, and what will they do to banks’ earnings and stock prices in the future?

articles.headline: The Gloomsayers Should Look Up
articles.snippet: This country does not look like a country in economic trouble.
articles.abstract: This country does not look like a country in economic trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEFORE I start on this little tour d’horizon, I just want to say that a good, fresh Taco Supreme from Taco Bell is more tasty than just about anything at any fancy-pants restaurant anywhere in the world. And they didn’t pay me, and they don’t even know me. Just for perspective.

articles.headline: Religious Right Divides Its Vote at Summit
articles.snippet: Christian conservatives were divided over which of the Republican presidential candidates to support.
articles.abstract: Christian conservatives were divided over which of the Republican presidential candidates to support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 — After an earnest appeal for acceptance from Rudolph W. Giuliani, Christian conservatives ended their two-day summit here Saturday still divided about which of the Republican presidential candidates to marshal their collective might behind.

articles.headline: Old Enough Now to Ask How Dad Died at War
articles.snippet: In a grim marker of the war’s longevity, children too young to remember losing a parent in Iraq are growing up.
articles.abstract: In a grim marker of the war’s longevity, children too young to remember losing a parent in Iraq are growing up.
articles.lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, N.Y. — CamerynLee was only 3 years old when her father, Lance Cpl. Eric J. Orlowski, a Marine Corps reservist, was killed in an accidental shooting during the first days of the Iraq war. Now 8, she is suddenly hungry for information about the man she remembers only in sketchy vignettes: Did he like chicken wings as much as she does? How about hockey? Was he funny?

articles.headline: In Pakistan Quandary, U.S.  Reviews Stance
articles.snippet: A political meltdown in Pakistan, where Al Qaeda, the Taliban, and nuclear weapons are all in play, could be a disaster for the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: A political meltdown in Pakistan, where Al Qaeda, the Taliban, and nuclear weapons are all in play, could be a disaster for the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 — The scenes of carnage in Pakistan this week conjured what one senior administration official on Friday called “the nightmare scenario” for President Bush’s last 15 months in office: Political meltdown in the one country where Al Qaeda, the Taliban, and nuclear weapons are all in play.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and David Rohde

articles.headline: Divide and Conquer: Meet the Lottery Titans
articles.snippet: With the domestic market plateauing, two U.S. lottery giants are focused on securing new footholds overseas.
articles.abstract: With the domestic market plateauing, two U.S. lottery giants are focused on securing new footholds overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Louisville, Ky.
articles.byline: By Ron Stodghill and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: In Myanmar, Fear Is Ever Present
articles.snippet: Anger, uncertainty and hopelessness lurk beneath the ominous calm that has settled in Yangon since the uprising last month.
articles.abstract: Anger, uncertainty and hopelessness lurk beneath the ominous calm that has settled in Yangon since the uprising last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar, Oct. 17 — Worshipers have begun returning to the Shwedagon Pagoda, the towering gold-coated landmark that had been cordoned off with soldiers and barbed wire only days before.

articles.headline: Tables Turned: Poor Countries Wag Fingers at Rich Ones
articles.snippet: In response to the global fallout from America’s housing troubles, developing nations are now lecturing the West on what they say are lax regulations and sleepy oversight.
articles.abstract: In response to the global fallout from America’s housing troubles, developing nations are now lecturing the West on what they say are lax regulations and sleepy oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 — The semiannual meetings of the world’s top finance and banking officials are predictable in one sense: Europeans and Americans often use them to lecture leaders of poor countries about the need to modernize their capital markets, promote transparency and adhere to sound investment standards.

articles.headline: A Protector as a Child, Honored as a Hero
articles.snippet: Two years after being killed in battle, Lt. Michael P. Murphy will become the first recipient of the nation’s highest military award for service in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Two years after being killed in battle, Lt. Michael P. Murphy will become the first recipient of the nation’s highest military award for service in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June 2005, Lt. Michael P. Murphy and three fellow members of the Navy Seals were on a mission in the mountains of Afghanistan when they were pinned down by a swarm of enemy fighters. Trapped in a steep ravine, they were unable to get a radio signal to call for help.

articles.headline: A Son of Immigrants Rises in a Southern State
articles.snippet: Bobby Jindal will be the nation’s first Indian-American governor in a state where race is inseparable from politics.
articles.abstract: Bobby Jindal will be the nation’s first Indian-American governor in a state where race is inseparable from politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 — The first words from Bobby Jindal to his supporters after he won the Louisiana governor’s race on Saturday night were not about his victory, but L.S.U.’s triumph over Auburn the same day.

articles.headline: Clinton Finds Way to Play Along With Drudge
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton is learning to play nice with the Drudge Report and the powerful, elusive man behind it.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton is learning to play nice with the Drudge Report and the powerful, elusive man behind it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 — As Senator Barack Obama prepared to give a major speech on Iraq one morning a few weeks ago, a flashing red-siren alert went up on the Drudge Report Web site. It read, “Queen of the Quarter: Hillary Crushes Obama in Surprise Fund-Raising Surge,” and, “$27 Million, Sources Tell Drudge Report.”

articles.headline: The Gospel According to Mr. Colbert
articles.snippet: Have you heard the one about the actor working as a comedian who plays a talk show host who is pretending to run for president?
articles.abstract: Have you heard the one about the actor working as a comedian who plays a talk show host who is pretending to run for president?
articles.lead_paragraph: Have you heard the one about the actor working as a comedian who plays a talk show host who is pretending to run for president?

articles.headline: Iraq and Turkey See Tensions Rise After Ambush
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice intervened to ward off a strike by Turkey in northern Iraq after Kurdish rebels killed at least 12 Turkish soldiers.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice intervened to ward off a strike by Turkey in northern Iraq after Kurdish rebels killed at least 12 Turkish soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL, Oct. 21 — A brazen ambush by Kurdish militants that left at least 12 Turkish soldiers dead touched off a major escalation in Turkey-Iraq tensions on Sunday, bringing fears that Turkey would retaliate immediately by sending troops across the border into Iraq. But Turkey’s prime minister said he delayed a decision, after Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice personally intervened.

articles.headline: Mortgage Security Bondholders Facing a Cutoff of Interest Payments
articles.snippet: Interest payment cutoffs, which are expected to accelerate, would be the latest blow to markets as investors try to anticipate the next problem that might shake confidence.
articles.abstract: Interest payment cutoffs, which are expected to accelerate, would be the latest blow to markets as investors try to anticipate the next problem that might shake confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the pain in the mortgage market, investors who hold bonds backed by risky home loans have continued to receive their monthly interest payments — until now.

articles.headline: As Apple Gains PC Market Share, Jobs Talks of a Decade of Upgrades
articles.snippet: Apple’s share of the personal computer market is surging, driven in part by what analysts call a halo effect from the iPod and the iPhone.
articles.abstract: Apple’s share of the personal computer market is surging, driven in part by what analysts call a halo effect from the iPod and the iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 — It may have dropped the word “computer” from its name, but Apple is certainly selling plenty of Macs.

articles.headline: Buyers Pounce on Deals as Homes Go on the Block
articles.snippet: Some investors see the misery of subprime loans, rising mortgage rates and slumping sales as an opportunity.
articles.abstract: Some investors see the misery of subprime loans, rising mortgage rates and slumping sales as an opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 21 — In a down real estate market, they came to buy. They came early, they came in numbers and they came with bank checks for $5,000.

articles.headline: Libraries Shun Deals to Place Books on Web
articles.snippet: Several major research libraries have rebuffed offers from Google and Microsoft to scan their books, instead signing on with a nonprofit effort.
articles.abstract: Several major research libraries have rebuffed offers from Google and Microsoft to scan their books, instead signing on with a nonprofit effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several major research libraries have rebuffed offers from Google and Microsoft to scan their books into computer databases, saying they are put off by restrictions these companies want to place on the new digital collections.

articles.headline: How Many Site Hits? Depends Who’s Counting
articles.snippet: Even though online advertising is growing fast, that growth is being stunted, industry executives say, because nobody can get the basic visitor counts straight.
articles.abstract: Even though online advertising is growing fast, that growth is being stunted, industry executives say, because nobody can get the basic visitor counts straight.
articles.lead_paragraph: How many people visited Style.com, the online home of Vogue and W magazines, last month? Was it 421,000, or, more optimistically, 497,000? Or was the real number more than three times higher, perhaps 1.8 million?
